title: Pls help. 3 fonts/19th+20th century
content:
Number 1 is not a typeface. It appears to be some kind of   
carved letters.   
   
Number 3 looks like Devinne Italic or, since it's in German,   
it could be Lateinisch, H. Berthold's Devinne look-alike.   
Neither of these is available digitally that I know of, but   
Bitstream's [Romana](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516141116/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/romana/) is very close. No italic unfortunately.   
   
Couldn't find the script in any of my books. Troubador has   
some similarities (such as the uppercase M).
author: Mark Simonson

comments.content:
You could approximate the look of number 1 in print by using [Helvetica Rounded Bold Condensed](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516141116/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/helveticarounded/) or similar.   
   
 ![Helvetica Rounded Sample](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516141116im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/19152.gif)

As Mark Simonson said, #3 it looks like Lateinisch from Berthold.   
   
I want to add that this font was digitized by a Russian foundry, ParaType ( [www.paratype.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516141116/http:/www.paratype.com/)). They named it Literaturnaya.   
   
The font was donated to public domain, but only for use in TeX applications. It can be found in various russian TeX archives, both PFB and metrics, but the encoding is for TeX. Be sure to read the licence, cause it is not quite a free font.
